oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Engine Company No. 6
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of Engine Company No. 6 on Second Avenue showing five firemen and four horses standing on a stone sidewalk in front of the entrance to the building. All of the horses are wearing bridles. The building has double doors with arched transom windows.

Engine House No. 6 is a two-story brick building located on South Market Street, around Elm Street, at what is now 629 Second Avenue. Engine Company No. 6 was first organized in 1860, making it one of Nashville's earliest engine companies. The company's name changed several times before it was named the James Geddes Engine Company No. 6 in 1887. The Engine House No. 6 was well-known for hosting largely attended Fourth of July barbeques at their Market Street location.
